I came across this list in a book, Ideas of the Great Philosophers by William S. and Mabel Lewis Sahakian:
 
 The Twelve Virtues according to Aristotle:
 
 Courage; Temperance; Liberality; Magnificence; Magnanimity; an unnamed virtue which lies between the Vice of Deficiency, Lack of Ambition and the Vice of Excess, (Over) Ambitiousness, so I'd think one could safely assume that this particular Virtue could be named Ambition; Gentleness; Truthfulness; Wittiness; Friendliness; Modesty; and Righteous Indignation.
 
 This was first published in 1966 and it seems to me that Righteous Indignation does not presently find favor as a virtue. Magnificence also seems to be a strange quality to be esteemed as a virtue, but it lies between the Vices of Meanness and Vulgarity so I'm wondering if it might refer to having good taste.
 
 I have not yet been able to find another source for these virtues but I would assume that they were listed in the original Greek texts of Aristotle. I wonder how these virtues would translate into modern values and if they would all meet the criteria of what is currently considered virtue.

 That's not quite how I see it. Both sets of virtues have some that simply relate to being good to people. Where they differ is that Western/Christian virtues also advocate not causing waves. This is seen with virtues like humility, obediance, and temperance. The Aristoleian virtues, on the other hand, seem to advocate doing great things, striving, and acheiving. This could be the difference between the outward looking culture of ancient Greece as opposed to the inward looking culture of medeval Europe. Ancient Greece was looking to expand its horizons, Europe wanted to maintain the status quo, and their respective virtues reflect this.

 Aren't all virtues social virtues? This is, a virtue is a quality that society thinks well of and wants to encourage. By looking at a list of virtues you can see what sort of person that society holds in highest regard, or at least the sort of person the people who published the list want people to try to be like. Aristotle's list may be an accurate mirror of Greek society, or it could be his attempt to push Greek society in a certain direction. I don't know enough Greek history to say one way or the other for certain.

The Aristotelian philosophy teaches that individuals should pursue the middle way between excess and deficiancy in all areas of life. He focuses on identifying the appropriate emotional and behavioural characteristics of response for for any given social situation. Since we are social beings, we interact with others and because of that we need to consider others as well in our behaviour. His virtues are those that he finds ideal for balanced interpersonal dealings. 
 But lets face it, we have all our inner needs that drive us to act. But how well we can 'control' it through our behaviour makes us virtuous. With this I mean that we don't act out as we had no control over our impulses but rather we find a way of restraning, not too much and not too little, our tendencies for the good of situation (which is a "mean" response according to Aristotles) and not vice versa.
